div.l: Ne at this tale I saw no man him greve
But it were only Oswold the Reve
Bicause he was of carpinters crafte
A litle Ire in his hert he rafte
He gan to grucche and blamed it a lite
So thike coth he ful wel I coude þee quite
With blering of a proude Milners eye
If that me lust to speke of ribaudy
But ic am olde me lust not pley for age
Grasse time is done my foddir is forage
This white toppe writith myn̄ olde yeris
Myn̄ hert is also moulid as is myn̄ heris
But if I fare as doth an open ars
That ilke frute is euer leng̉er the wars
Til it be roten in mulloc or in stree
We olde men I drede so fare we
Til we be roten can we not be ripe
We hoppen alwey whils the world wil pipe
For in oure wille ther stikith euer anayle
To haue an hore berd and a grene taile
As hath a leke for theigh our͗e might be gon̄
Oure wille desirith foly euer in one
For whan we may not do þan wil we speke
Yit in oure asshen olde · ther is fire y reke
Four thingis han we which I shal diuise
Avaunting lying Angre and couetise
Thees foure sparclis longen vnto elde
Oure old lymmes may wel be vnwelde
But wille shal not faile that is sothe
And yit haue I alwey a coltis tothe
As many a yere as it is passid henne
Sith my tappe of lif bigan to renne
For sicurly whan I was born̄ anon̄
Deth drue the tappe of lif and lete it ge gon̄ge gon̄
And euer͗e sith hath the tappe y rıı̄unne
Til that almost al empty is the tıı̄unne
The streme of lif now droppith on þe chymbe
The celi tunge may wel rynge ⁊and clymbe
Of wrechidnesse that passid is ful yore
With olde folk saue dotage ther is no more
And whan that oure host had herd þis ʆsermonȳng
He gan to speke as lordly as a kyng
And seid what amountith alle this witte
